I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  Investment in high quality private infrastructure sector projects in Central, West and South 
Asia requires extensive project preparatory market research and study, followed by identification, 
early-stage  screening,  origination,  preparation,  and  processing  of  commercially  viable 
nonsovereign transactions for potential ADB private sector participation. An important part of such 
activities also entails identification of potential integrity, reputational, and money laundering risks 
and designing appropriate mitigation measures. The proposed transaction technical assistance 
(TA) is designed to undertake this particular activity of due diligence. The TA will complement 
ADB’s own efforts, research and transaction support and portfolio management activities with 
respect to integrity due diligence (IDD) issues. 
 
2.  Reducing poverty in Asia and the Pacific requires strong private sector engagement to 
address key development and infrastructure gaps, stable trade opportunities, and creation of 
gainful employment. As per recent studies, South Asia and Central/West Asia (the subject matter 
of this proposed TA) needs to invest an average of $400 billion annually in infrastructure until 
2030 to maintain its growth momentum and tackle poverty,1 excluding the cost of responding to 
climate change (in which case the amount is pegged at $460 billion). Private sector investment in 
infrastructure and enhancing efficiency of infrastructure services is crucial to meet this need. 
While there has already been a robust growth in the region in recent years with substantial private 
sector engagement, the ADB is committed to significantly increase its private sector support 
through providing financing and support to commercially viable private sector projects. 
 
3.  Corruption, fraud, and money laundering harm economic development and hinder efforts 
to reduce poverty—and have emerged as one of the key development challenges in the Asia and 
Pacific.  To address this, ADB’s Anticorruption Policy requires ADB projects and staff to adhere 
to the highest standards in these regards.2 The primary objective of this TA is to help address this 
key development gap by preparing a pipeline of private sector projects in developing member 
countries of Central, West, and South Asian region that would meet ADB’s stringent requirements 
laid out in its policies, procedures and guidelines relating to IDD.3 
 
4.  The TA responds directly to ADB’s Strategy 2030—which calls for expanding private 
sector operations by providing financing and promoting high standards of corporate governance, 
integrity, transparency, and social and environmental safeguards.4 The TA is also consistent with 
ADB’s operational plan for private sector operations, 2019–2024, which requires ADB to promote 
the highest level of integrity in its operations, be disciplined and selective, and ensure that lending 
and investment decisions are based on a thorough understanding of the risks and that risks and 
rewards are balanced appropriately.5 
 
 
 
 
 
1  ADB. 2017. Meeting Asia’s Infrastructure Needs. Manila.  
2  ADB. 1998. Anticorruption Policy. Manila.  
3  (Confidential information redacted.) 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
5  ADB. 2019. Operational Plan for Private Sector Operations, 2019–2024. Manila.

2 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
5.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) private sector investment in infrastructure 
in Central, West and South Asia region enhanced, (ii) development impact as the key objective 
of private sector pursued, and (iii) private sector projects meeting best-practice integrity standards 
prepared. The TA will have the following outcome: ADB’s private sector infrastructure investment, 
complying with its integrity standards, increased in Central, West and South Asia. 
 
6.  Output 1: Private sector projects in infrastructure sector identified and screened, 
and IDD undertaken. The TA will support all required IDD and know-your-customer (KYC) 
checks of private infrastructure sector projects in Central, West and South Asia (including those 
processed under One-ADB approach). It will encompass the entire project processing cycle. The 
TA will help identify and screen infrastructure sector projects - that would meet ADB’s integrity 
requirements  -  during  the  period  2021–2023.  The  IDD  process  generally  comprises:  the 
identification and investigations (as needed) of ultimate beneficial owners, shareholders, senior 
executives, affiliates, subsidiaries, significant contracting entities, and other key counterparties as 
required under ADB’s relevant procedures and guidelines on IDD (footnote 3). Based on the 
above assessments, significant or potentially significant integrity risks will be identified and 
evaluated in coordination with the Private Sector Transaction Support division of PSOD, the Office 
of Anticorruption and Integrity, and the Office of General Counsel. It is expected that the number 
of project leads initially screened will amount to at least 20 per annum. 
 
7.  Output  2:  Capacity  development  of  private  sector  companies  to  meet  ADB’s 
integrity requirements for private sector investment. This output will enhance potential 
borrowers’/sponsors’ project preparatory efforts through improved awareness of ADB’s strategic 
priorities and requirements on the IDD front, and close cooperation at an early stage. The TA will 
support the readiness of a project from an integrity perspective by engaging consultants who will 
provide specialized knowledge and expertise in the area of integrity due diligence to help private 
sector sponsors to meet requirements under ADB’s relevant procedures and guidelines on IDD 
(footnote 3). The consultants will advise and provide guidance to the borrowers/sponsors on the 
IDD process and on the relevance and adequacy of the KYC documents and information provided. 
Number of projects made ready for ADB financing is expected to be at least 10–15 by July 2023. 
 
8.  Output 3: Solutions identified to mitigate IDD related risks in ADB’s private sector 
projects. This output will focus on resolving and mitigating integrity risks, if any, as the key 
component of ADB’s project cycle processing. Consultants will advise project team leads on 
potential mitigants and such recommendations may result in structural changes, that will enable 
the successful closure of infrastructure sector nonsovereign projects. It is expected that integrity 
risks and proposed mitigants will be documented in the IDD Checklists of at least 10 projects, and 
such projects will be assessed by the Office of Anticorruption and Integrity. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $372,000 which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  ($221,400,  TASF-donor  contribution,  $150,600,  TASF-
income transfer).  The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.

3 
D.  Implementation Arrangements

execute and administer the TA, with support from PSTS. The implementation arrangements are

11.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.6  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
12.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $372,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting Integrity Due Diligence for Private Sector Infrastructure Projects in the Central, West 
and South Asia Region, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
